summary: This paper investigates the relationship between narrative style, misinformation, and user engagement on Twitter, finding a connection between narrativity and higher engagement. The study utilizes GPT models and statistical modeling to support its claims. The paper has been improved by clarifications regarding existing content, but still requires improvements in reproducibility, ethical considerations, and the generalizability of its findings.

strengths.text: The paper compares GPT-3 text-davinci-003 performance with gpt-3.5-turbo and other models, presenting results in tables. (Table 2, Table 3, Table 9, Table 10)
The study demonstrates a connection between narrativity and higher user engagement, and misinformation and lower engagement, supported by statistical modeling. (Sec 7)
Figure 1 provides a clear visual representation of the prompt components used for the GPT models. (Fig 1)
Tables 6, 7, and 12 include statistical testing (Mann-Whitney U test) and provide ratios (R) to compare means, along with color-coding to highlight significant differences. (Tables 6, 7, 12)
The paper's focus on the interplay between narrative style and misinformation on Twitter engagement is novel, building upon existing literature. (Intro)
The methodology, including annotation of tweets for narrative style and the use of text classifiers, is a clear advancement over prior work. (Related Work)
The paper includes a baseline comparison with bag-of-words models with ngram features in Section 4.2 and Table 3, demonstrating the effectiveness of the deep learning models.

weaknesses.text: The paper lacks information on the specific random seeds and environment used, hindering reproducibility. (Section 4.1)
The paper overclaims the generalizability of its findings, focusing solely on Twitter data without sufficient evidence for other platforms or contexts. (Sec 7)
The paper does not provide a detailed analysis of the limitations of the GPT models, such as their sensitivity to prompt engineering or potential biases. (Insufficient evidence)
Figure 2 lacks clear axis labels and units, making it difficult to interpret the data. (Fig 2)
The paper lacks crucial information regarding ethical considerations, including consent, privacy measures, and data usage terms. (Insufficient evidence)
The paper does not explicitly discuss potential ethical risks, such as the amplification of misinformation or manipulation of user engagement. (Insufficient evidence)

Tables 1, 2, 3, 9, and 10 lack standard deviations, confidence intervals, or p-values, making it difficult to assess the statistical significance of the results. Table 8 lacks any statistical information. (Tables 1, 2, 3, 8, 9, 10)
The paper lacks a clear definition of 'user engagement' and the metrics used to measure it. (Abstract, Introduction ยง1)
The paper does not explicitly discuss potential biases in the datasets or models, nor does it address fairness considerations. (Insufficient evidence)
The paper does not discuss the specific features or architectures used in the text classifiers in detail. (Methods)

suggestions.text: Provide the specific seeds used for each experiment and include a section detailing the environment used (e.g., Python version, library versions, hardware) to improve reproducibility. (Section 4.1)
Provide a link to the code repository. (All sections)
Conduct experiments on different datasets or platforms to validate the generalizability of the findings. (Sec 7)
Provide a more detailed analysis of the limitations of the GPT models, including their sensitivity to prompt engineering and potential biases. (Insufficient evidence)
For Figure 2, add axis labels and units (if applicable). Include a legend to clarify the categories. (Fig 2)

Include a section detailing the data collection process, including how consent was obtained or if data was publicly available and how it was handled. Detail any privacy-preserving measures. (Insufficient evidence)
Provide a clear statement on data usage terms, including any restrictions on redistribution or commercial use. (Insufficient evidence)
Add a section discussing potential ethical risks (e.g., spread of misinformation, privacy violations) and mitigation strategies. (Insufficient evidence)
If the data is from Twitter, clarify adherence to Twitter's terms of service and developer policies. (Insufficient evidence)

Include standard deviations or confidence intervals to indicate the variability of the results. Add p-values to show the statistical significance of the differences between models or configurations. For Table 8, include counts and percentages. (Tables 2, 3, 9, 10)
Provide a more detailed explanation of the annotation process, including the guidelines used to identify narrative style in tweets. (Introduction ยง1)
Define 'user engagement' and specify the metrics used to measure it (e.g., retweets, likes, replies). (Abstract, Introduction ยง1)
Consider adding a table summarizing the key notations used throughout the paper for clarity. (Throughout)
Add a Broader Impact section with mitigation strategies. (Conclusion)
Conduct a comparative experiment using the TweetEval benchmark to evaluate the performance of the proposed text classifiers against existing state-of-the-art models. (Sec 3.1)
